Enjoy the rest of the trip!

- Alison Eisel Hendricks

item.title: Comment on "Blog 2"
item.description:
You might consider looking into a mifi device to help you with the internet issue. Essentially, it's a mobile wifi hotspot that you can keep in your pocket, and in most countries, you can get one without a contract.

Some mifi models are like USBs that you pop into your computer to use, but if you can find a standalone device, it would make it easy to use on the go with an iPod touch or a smartphone.

Try stopping in a few cell phone shops around the city, and just ask if they carry them. If you do a bit of homework online first, it will probably also help you to figure out which stores might carry them.

- COLLEEN PATRICIA BALUKAS

item.title: Comment on "Confession: Public transportation scares me"
item.description:
Great story-telling! I completely understand the scariness of learning your way around a new bus system, especially in a new country. You never know what to expect!

Strangely, I find the most chaotic bus systems are the most comfortable for me. Missed bus stops and non-functioning buttons? Totally irrelevant in a chaotic system, when a shout to the bus driver will stop the bus literally anywhere - even in the middle of a traffic jam, or two feet after the last person's invented stop. There's no way to go wrong.

Hope you're getting the hang of everything now. I'm sure you'll get used to it all quickly!

- COLLEEN PATRICIA BALUKAS

item.title: Comment on "My Attempt at Philosophical Thinking"
item.description:
Ben - Running on the streets, especially a la hora de tapas is probably also a give-away that you're not granadino! But that's ok. It's a very safe place. I walked the streets of Granada alone as a woman after dark and never had any issues/fears. And if you didn't explore those places on your runs, you might miss them completely! That would be a much bigger shame.

- AMELIA JANE DIETRICH

item.title: Comment on "Week 1 - Getting acquainted"

item.title: Comment on "Week 1 - Introduction"
item.description:
Ben - sounds like you're having a great experience. It's hard not to in Granada!

1) You will FOREVER miss tapas once you leave Grana'...by the way, Granada is the only place they are always free and also fabulous. If you haven't hit up the tapas scene on Calle Elvira yet, you must! There's a bar run by Italians right inside la Puerta Elvira (near Caitlin's place) who always has good and different tapas (think: pasta? soup? fabulous!)

2) Keep smiling through! It never hurts!

and 3) Code-switching is not only a linguistic phenomenon, it is also a culturally constrained and community-based phenomenon. Our little bilingual community in Giuli's lab is a big fan of hablando whatever we want cuando sea but despite the presence of some highly proficient SLLs and a lot of foreign tourists, Granada is really a monolingual community. (Which is ok, because we often go there in search of monolinguals, right?)

- AMELIA JANE DIETRICH

item.title: Comment on "Bicycles and stroopwafels"
item.description:
Good to know there's peanut butter in the Netherlands! My mom spent a fortune shipping it to me in Italy - a girl just can't live without that stuff! Also, that empty space where your peanut butter used to be in your suitcase can no be filled with cute European fashion. :)

- AMELIA JANE DIETRICH

item.title: Comment on "Conquering the City and the Language"
item.description:
Leah - I'm so pleased to hear that you made it to Berlin and are settling in! Congratulations on surviving that lab meeting in German (ERP studies in German could not have been an easy topic to understand!). It's also wonderful to hear that you've already tested 9 participants - way to go! As Dr. Dussias said above, I too look forward to seeing your pictures of the city! :)

- COURTNEY E J FOWLER

item.title: Comment on "Confession: Public transportation scares me"
item.description:

With your fantastic attitude, I have no doubt Nijmegen will be a wonderful experience for you.

- PAOLA EULALIA DUSSIAS

item.title: Comment on "My Attempt at Philosophical Thinking"
item.description:
I knew exactly where you were! I get lost very easily in Granada, not because of the city layout, but because unlike you, I have no internal compass. Granada is a wonderful city to get lost in. No matter where you end up, you'll find a beautiful callejón.

And thank you for sending me your first participant's data. I'll be looking at it this weekend. Can't wait to see what your first participant has done!

Abrazos!

- PAOLA EULALIA DUSSIAS

item.title: Comment on "Conquering the City and the Language"

item.title: Comment on "Watermelon in China"

- COURTNEY E J FOWLER
